dt: {bc}a government in which the supreme power is {d_link|vested|vest:2} in the people and exercised by them directly or indirectly through a system of representation usually involving periodically held free {d_link|elections|election}
{bc}a political unit that has a {a_link|democratic} government
{bc}the principles and policies of the Democratic party in the U.S.

dt.t: from emancipation Republicanism to New Deal {it}Democracy{/it}

dt: {bc}the {d_link|common|common:1} people especially when constituting the source of political authority
{bc}the absence of {d_link|hereditary|hereditary} or {d_link|arbitrary|arbitrary} class distinctions or privileges

quotes.t: {qword}Democracy{/qword}, I would repeat, is the noblest form of government we have yet evolved …

… this and the economic failures of faithful {qword}democracies{/qword} in places such as India or the Anglophone Caribbean demonstrated conclusively that there was no inherent link between freedom and capitalism …
Even in {qword}democracies{/qword} today, crucial knowledge is available to only a few individuals …

et: borrowed from Middle French {it}democracie, democratie,{/it} borrowed from Late Latin {it}dēmocratia,{/it} borrowed from Greek {it}dēmokratía,{/it} from {it}dēmo-{/it} {et_link|demo-|demo-} + {it}-kratia{/it} {et_link|-cracy|-cracy}
shortdef: government by the people; especially : rule of the majority
a government in which the supreme power is vested in the people and exercised by them directly or indirectly through a system of representation usually involving periodically held free elections
a political unit that has a democratic government

dt: {bc}democracy in which the power is exercised directly by the people rather than through representatives

shortdef: democracy in which the power is exercised directly by the people rather than through representatives

dt: {bc}a political movement advocating a gradual and peaceful transition from capitalism to socialism by democratic means
{bc}a democratic welfare state that incorporates both capitalist and socialist practices

pt: In the many years since {i_link|socialism|socialism} entered English around 1830, it has acquired several different meanings. It refers to a system of social organization in which private property and the distribution of income are subject to social control, but the conception of that control has varied, and the term has been interpreted in widely diverging ways, ranging from {d_link|statist|statism} to libertarian, from {d_link|Marxist|Marxism} to liberal. In the modern era, "pure" socialism has been seen only rarely and usually briefly in a few Communist regimes. Far more common are systems of {i_link|social democracy|social democracy}, now often referred to as {it}democratic socialism{/it}, in which extensive state regulation, with limited state ownership, has been employed by democratically elected governments (as in Sweden and Denmark) in the belief that it produces a fair distribution of income without impairing economic growth.

shortdef: a political movement advocating a gradual and peaceful transition from capitalism to socialism by democratic means
a democratic welfare state that incorporates both capitalist and socialist practices

dt: {bc}a political philosophy advocating preservation of established institutions and traditional principles combined with political democracy and a social and economic program designed to benefit the common man

shortdef: a political philosophy advocating preservation of established institutions and traditional principles combined with political democracy and a social and economic program designed to benefit the common man
